body:
Via local builds I was able to isolate the problematic commit: https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/dc69a943c3682fec16845828cb6d8f0554fad61f

Still not sure what this breaks - we're using standard PEM format like:

```
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<a bunch of base 64>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
```

with none of the newlines this commit seems to address.
@andrewparmet I guess you can't share the pem file ?

Unfortunately not. I've been able to narrow it down a bit:

- Parsing does work on the JVM - this is only an Android issue
- The text returned by [`m.group(0)` here](https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/aa59245955f5121c4230d46c41a4b7f55e0c9ba7/handler/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/ssl/PemReader.java#L92) is simply `BEGIN` - which is not right at all. I'd have a hard time believing it, but is there a difference between the regex implementations on the JVM and Android?
hmm... sounds like an android bug then...
Filed: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/293206296 and we'll see what comes back.

rename.from: SSL certificate parsing issue when upgrading beyond 4.1.78
rename.to: SSL certificate parsing issue when upgrading beyond 4.1.78 on Android

body:
Hi there,
I have the same issue here. 

I did some research and found that this is probably not an Android issue.
PemReader class uses regex to parse the certificates from the InputStream, but the thing is that regex works differently in JVM and Android Runtime.
https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/285ba74f899866ddf3e23a6770c954e350245bd7/handler/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/ssl/PemReader.java#L84C1-L90C14
PemReader expects that after matching the header the matcher moves the cursor to a position after the header and it works this way in JVM but it doesn't in Android and the certificate body is matched starting from the beginning of the string as just "BEGIN". And this is why the conversion to an X509 certificate instance fails.

This can be fixed by calling the find() method with the next position after the header as a parameter, or by using the BouncyCastle PEMParser as it's done for the private key.
@fishb1 if you know how to fix it please open a PR and we will review it

You first say:

> this is probably not an Android issue

Then you say:

> regex works differently in JVM and Android Runtime

To me this seems like the definition of "Android issue" but if you have a workaround that fixes the implementation on Android while not breaking it on the JVM, then to me that seems like only mild debt (when paired with comment to undo the hack and a link to the Android bug that I filed and Google accepted).

In any case we've migrated to using binary certificate files instead of text so we're not held hostage by this bug anymore.

> To me this seems like the definition of "Android issue" but if you have a workaround that fixes the implementation on Android while not breaking it on the JVM, then to me that seems like only mild debt (when paired with comment to undo the hack and a link to the Android bug that I filed and Google accepted).
> 

Ahhh, I see now! I expected that usePatten() method reset the latest match position but I read the doc for the method again and it said that the position should not be affected. 

Thanks for submitting this! 

But I think a fix needs to be done anyway to make Netty work in older SDKs, even if Google fixes the regex issue in future versions.

issue.title: Workaround for regex bug in Android SDK

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

If Netty is started from an Android app and certificate/private key are passed into the builder as input streams, an error occurs: org.conscrypt.OpenSSLX509CertificateFactory: org.conscrypt.OpenSSLX509CertificateFactory: java.lang.RuntimeException: error:0c0000a2:ASN.1 encoding routines:OPENSSL_internal:NOT_ENOUGH_DATA

Due to a bug in the regex implementation in Android SDK, the certificate is parsed from the input stream as BEGIN and further creating of the X.509 certificate fails.

See https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/293206296 

Modifications:

The end position of the latest match is saved into a variable and used as the start position for the next match as a workaround for the bug.

Result:

Fixes #13515

Netty starts on Android without an error.
